message.content:
<<<api>>>: ImageMagick
<<<code>>>: 
```java
import java.awt.Color;
import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;
import java.io.File;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Iterator;
import java.util.Map;
import javax.imageio.ImageIO;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        File file= new File("path_to_your_image");
        BufferedImage image = ImageIO.read(file);
        int height = image.getHeight();
        int width = image.getWidth();
        Map m = new HashMap();
        for(int i=0; i < width ; i++){
            for(int j=0; j < height ; j++){
                int pixel = image.getRGB(i,j);
                Color color = new Color(pixel, true);
                int red = color.getRed();
                int green = color.getGreen();
                int blue = color.getBlue();
                int alpha = color.getAlpha();
                int[] rgb = new int[]{red,green,blue,alpha};
                int counter = m.containsKey(rgb) ? (Integer) m.get(rgb) : 0;
                m.put(rgb, counter+1);
            }
        }
        int counter = 0;
        int[] dominantColor = new int[4];
        for(Iterator i = m.entrySet().iterator(); i.hasNext();){
            Map.Entry entry = (Map.Entry) i.next();
            int[] key = (int[]) entry.getKey();
            int value = (Integer) entry.getValue();
            if(counter < value){
                counter = value;
                dominantColor = key;
            }
        }
        System.out.println("Dominant Color : "+dominantColor[0]+","+dominantColor[1]+","+dominantColor[2]+","+dominantColor[3]);
    }
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: This code reads an image and gets the RGB and alpha values of each pixel. It then counts the occurrence of each color in a HashMap. The color with the highest count is the dominant color. The dominant color is then printed out.
